If you take religion out of the picture for a minute....and look at what science and psychology knows about addictions. Just about anything can become and addiction. People are addicted to shopping, the internet, web forums.....why not religion?
 
 It is all about the dopimine (spelling?) The brain shoots out a set of chemicals the give people a high....some drugs intensify this.....some religious experineces do the same.
Truthsayer

Self induced delusions. It's a lifelong challenge within one's self to convince one's self of the obviously impossible. The resulting product is called faith. I think the dopamine theory isn't far off either. Some people get extreme emotional highs from religion, especially within the charismatic movements.
 
 It's also group therapy. It's an oppertunity for believers to gather and reinforce their delusional fantasies with each other. It's a crutch to overcome the fear of death as well. For the most part it's harmless unless taken to the extreme. However, it can be rather obnoxious. But the purpose it serves in some people makes it a valuable commodity I suppose.
 
 Myself, I do not require the religious masquerade. Truth and reality suit me just fine. emoticon_idea

Not all drugs are bad, even if one become dependent on them.

 Well, no it isn't. It is not really and analogy at all. People do get addicted to religion. It can get in the way of some people's lives. Say your have been threatened by your boss to stop trying to convert people in the break room, but you just cannot do it. You get fired from your job. That sounds like an addiction to me.
 
 We are also not saying here that it happens to alot of people but certainly it does happen. If people can get addicted to shopping or porn, why would you have a hard time accepting that people get addicted to religion.

Well, no it isn't. It is not really and analogy at all. People do get addicted to religion. It can get in the way of some people's lives.  We are also not saying here that it happens to alot of people but certainly it does happen. If people can get addicted to shopping or porn, why would you have a hard time accepting that people get addicted to religion.

 
 On the other hand, I have known SOME people who traded one addiction for another. Trading in an alcohol habit for a religious addiction (or another drug) can often be less destructive. Of course, this assumes that the person in question is able to use his/her new addiction to keep off the old one.

Personaly i'm not consider to myself and not even close as an highly religious individual, however regardless all foolishness what there can be said whether religion may be considered as a drug or whether god is a human creation instead of god had there created to the man, etc. what i do regard as for certain is that any religion (and in this context i myself speaking pretty much seriusly only considered as valid religions not more than a fistful of them), gives us mainly a couple stuffs that on my view are important to rely on life, they are:
 1.- All the people ever since the world is world and the people is people, has had the need to believe in something, that be there also known as faith, well faith is important to have throughout life whether this faith can be there translated for some of us in hope or for others as an reinforcement of their own personality or even going further whatever you want to match it at, would be valid to do, faith i think is core to have in life.
 2.- i think probabily at least on my view the most important thing that religion (at least the catholic one whose i'm a "faithful" by the way) may provide for us is as such its face as a restraint as well as a guide to abide by, this is still more sharped to be there regarded as a legacy for the youth since the formation of a solid criteria is still weak upon them and takes time to be got, so they need to have close to them some normative and some frame of reference to be grabbed at, not to miss their behave compass and to repel bad influenzes that over there might arise.
 So to me at least what the catholic religion preaches (i can speak out about this religion now that is mine's and therefore is what i know better) is nowhere near wrong teachings or wrong doings to be spreaded, but very much so on the contrary trend is a good advice to be stuck at and bear in mind throughout mine's or anybody's life, so as long as something makes for you bringing up to your life good stuffs to set out why the heck would i have to condemn it soarly as plenty people over there seems to do?.

 That some people need drugs to live a meaningful life is self evident. Drugs such as insulin allows insulin dependent diabetes to lead productive lives.
 That some people similarly benefit from religion is also self evident.
 
 A religion free world would still be filled with atrocities, if not more so, than the one we live in now.
 That religion is perversed to serve an individuals needs does not abrogate its positive value for others, or in itself.
 
 
 The comparative argument of God to drug is a simpleton's attempt at refutting the role of religion in life.

I know plenty of people who cannot live without their daily shots ... of insulin.
 My point is that certain drugs are required. Religion is one such.
 The argument that religion is a drug, implying it is therefore bad, is a poor analogy.

 
 
 You are correct, some drugs are good when used properly. We are talking about abuse, not maintenence. We are saying when peoples religion becomes and addiction, which that does happen. Maybe we should define addiction first and then see if some people fit that definition when it comes to religion.
 
 Here is one definition:
 Addiction is defined as the compulsive need for and use of something that is psychologically or physically habit-forming, characterized by tolerance and by well-defined physiological symptoms upon withdrawal; Being abnormally tolerant to and dependent upon a habit forming substance.
 
 
 Here is an interesting questionerre on addiction and religion....
 
 Are you wondering whether you might be a religion addict instead of a Christian? Here are a few questions that might help you decide . . .
 
 Do you fear that God will turn his back on you if you do not do enough for him?
 
 Do you give money to a church or ministry in order for God to bless you?
 
 Do you often tell your spouse or children what to do without explaining your reasons, just because you know you are right?
 
 Do you have to check with your minister or a trusted interpreter of Scripture in order to decide your position on some spiritual issue?
 
 Do you believe you are still being punished by God for something you did a long time ago?
 
 Do you think that if you worker harder for him, God will eventually forgive you?
 http://rubelshelly.ibelieve.com/content.asp?CID=10450

 How about the pictures in gay pride parades when they're grabbing body parts and making sexual expressions with their tongues and painted faces, and flaunting their illicit gay sex sin in God's face?? 
 
 You want to talk drugs and alcohol, Matthew? 
 
 1989 - A study by McKirnan and Peterson revealed that while a higher proportion of gays and lesbians used alcohol or other drugs, the increase was in moderate, not heavy, use. 
 
 1992 - Skinner and Otis found that lesbians and gay men are less likely to abstain from alcohol and drugs and have a higher frequency of drinking than their non-gay counterparts. 
 
 1993 - A study of lesbians and substance use by Bloomfield found that lesbians reported a higher incidence of problems when they drink compared to non-gay women, although both groups have similar drinking rates.
 
 http://www.rci.rutgers.edu/~sydni/glfs.htm
 
 Not long ago a homosexual advocacy group called the Gay and Lesbian Medical Association admitted what's been common knowledge for a long time. The homosexual lifestyle is unhealthy. A report by the group shows that practicing homosexuals face a whole array of diseases and health problems at a higher rate than the general public. For instance, they admitted that homosexual men suffer from HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases at much higher rates than normal. And lesbian women face higher incidence of gynecological cancer. The report also found that homosexuals face a higher incidence of drug and alcohol abuse, depression, and anxiety.  
 
 http://www.mfc.org/contents/transcript.asp?id=1308
